Automated Correspondence Exam (ACE) Processing Overview
Table of Contents
Program Scope and Objectives
and (

) Program Overview: Automated Correspondence Exam (ACE) is an IRS developed, multifunctional software application that fully automates the tion and movement of Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) and Non-EITC through the audit process. (
) Purpose: This IRM provides guidance to personnel responsible for overseeing the daily functioning of the ACE processing system. (
) Audience: Wage and Investment (W&I) and Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) Examination. (
) Policy Owner: The Director of Refundable Credits Program Management (RCPM),Wage and Investment Division and The Director of Operations Support, Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE). (
) Program Owner: The Director of Refundable Credits Program Management (RCPM). (
) Primary Stakeholders: Wage and Investment (W&I), Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE). (
) Contact Information: To recommend changes or make any other suggestions for this IRM section send an email to the IRM author or utilize the SERP Feedback Application. (
) In

, the ACE system replaced Batch Processing (BP). ACE was created process speciﬁed cases with minimal to no tax examiner (TE) involvement a reply is received from the taxpayer. ACE processes cases from the of the Initial Contact Letter (ICL) through the Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency until closing. Cases can be reintroduced into ACE after a reply has been reviewed. (
) Congress has delegated to the IRS the responsibility of administering the laws, known as the Internal Revenue Code, found in Title
of the United States Code. (

) Automated Correspondence Exam (ACE) , is an IRS-developed, multifunc- tional software application that fully automates the initiation, Aging and Closing of certain Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) and Non-EITC cases. Using ACE, Correspondence Exam can process speciﬁed cases with minimal to no tax examiner (TE) involvement until a taxpayer reply is received. Because the system will automatically process the case through creation, statutory notice and closing, TE involvement is eliminated entirely on no-reply cases. Once taxpayer reply has been considered, the case can be reintroduced into ACE automated Aging and Closing in most instances. (

) ACE processing provides the service with four signiﬁcant capabilities: • Audit cases can be processed without TE involvement until taxpayer correspondence is received, unless a case ﬁlters out or manual classiﬁ- cation is required. • ACE will, on a weekly basis, create inventory records and case data (address and return information) for every case that has been opened on the Audit Information Management System (AIMS).
Additional Acronyms can be found on Acronyms Database (irs.gov) .

Audit cases can be processed without TE involvement until taxpayer correspondence is received, unless a case ﬁlters out or manual classiﬁ

cation is required. ACE will, on a weekly basis, create inventory records and case data (address and return information) for every case that has been opened on the Audit Information Management System (AIMS).
• ACE initiated cases can be reintroduced (returned to ACE after being removed for mail processing or case correction) to ACE Group B
for systemic Aging and Closing, if the case is a Project Code that goes through Create II. • After the report is created, manually initiated cases can be introduced ACE Group B
for systemic Aging and Closing. If the case is a Project Code that goes through Create II, it can be manually created and intro- duced in Status
and then aged through Create II. (
) Within ACE, the following actions take place automatically without human inter- vention.

Note: In most instances, cases in Statuses 10, 22, 23, 24, 25, and 53 can be rein- troduced into the ACE process for automated Aging and Closing.
CPS provides printing, inserting, sorting and mailing of IRS notices. A phased migration plan is being used to transition the notices from the campuses to the
CPS sites. The two consolidated print sites are CPS East in Detroit and CPS West in Ogden. The campuses are aligned to a print site based on their location (see chart below).
CPS East -- Detroit CPS CPS West -- Ogden Andover Austin Atlanta Fresno Brookhaven Kansas City Cincinnati Ogden Philadelphia Memphis
) How CPS works at the ACE Stage - Each case is systemically reviewed to determine if the individual package meets the print requirements (the individual package is within the
printed page limit (

oz.)) and the required schedules are templated for CPS. If the case meets these requirements, it is marked for processing through CPS. If the case does not meet these requirements it is marked for local mailout through print manager.
If the ICL package is not mailed through CPS:
The ACE Created letter and report will create in the Print Manager Program for local printing and mailing.
The ACE Created letter and report will create in the Print Manager Program for local printing and mailing. (
) Weekly ﬁles are received for cases selected through Dependent Database (DDB) pre-refund ﬁlters, as well as for Recertiﬁcation cases, Pickup cases, AM
ﬁles and the Tickler Files. They are assigned to one of three groups used in ACE processing. See below:
Automated Correspondence Exam (ACE) Processing Overview 4.19.20

ACE Group Actions Description B0 Cases from all ACE processes may be ﬁltered to or assigned to this group. The process systemically: • generates the letters and reports for mailing or review • computes tax • creates RGS work center ﬁles (RTF data, etc.) • creates an inventory record in RGS Groups B0, B1 or B2 • inputs RGS case history items • updates the RGS summary record (with four tabs: up- dateable data, case data; return informa- tion and historical data) • inputs RGS issues with associated paragraphs,MandatoryIssues,WorkpapernotationsandPenaltyConsider-ation • generates reports (found in UCP and Print Manager) • generates pending AIMS updates B1 Cases from ACE processes may be ﬁltered to or assigned to this group. Some cases are directed to Group B1 for manual input of the issues and creation of the letters and reports by the examiners. Rejects may be directed to this group. 4.19.20 page 5

ACE Group Actions Description B2 Cases from ACE pro- cessing may be ﬁltered to or assigned to this group. Some cases are directed to Group B2 for programs that require a report to be sent with the initial contact letter. The report must be reviewed prior to issuance to the taxpayer. Other cases are ﬁltered to Group B2 and require a reject condition and an associ- ated notice. 4.19 Liability Determination
The ﬁrst step in ACE processing is the ﬁlter process. B0 processing is suspended on all cases meeting an unresolved ﬁlter condition.

The ICL for EITC cases is the CP
notice series. The ICL for Discretionary cases is the Letter
-S. The CP
notice series also serves as the refund delay letter. The CP
notice series and Letter

-S address the speciﬁc issues selected for examination on the return, and include the appropriate paragraphs describing the documentation needed to substantiate the issues under examination. No report (Form
) is issued as part of the CP
notice series or Letter
-S mail out. The CP
notice series will be generated at master ﬁle, while the Letter
-S package will be generated
4.19.20.2.1(01-01-2023) B0 – ACE Create/Tax Computation
during Create I for CPS mailing. As a result of this ICL processing, the ACE Create process is broken down to two separate processes.
Only programs which use the CP 75 notice series or Letter 566-S as the require both Create I and Create II processing.

Letter 2194, Letter 1862, and Letter 525 with report Form 4549 are used as the ICL on some of the other Discretionary programs. Programs using these letters for initial contact will only process through Create I.
For those programs where the ICL is the CP 75 notice series, or the Letter 566-S , the ACE Create I process will:
Create Inventory Records Create Program related Issues and paragraphs Create History Items Create pending AIMS update to Status
Create appropriate suspense dates, based on the type case
When the Create II process runs, it will identify those cases in Status 10 with the appropriate suspense date for generating the Letter 525 and report, Form 4549.
For those programs where the Letter 566-B, Letter 2194, or Letter 525 with report is the ICL, the Create I process will:
Create Inventory Records Create Issues and paragraphs Create History Item Create pending AIMS update to Status
Create appropriate suspense date, based on the program Route the case to Group B
for review and future processing if necessary
The system will consist of four user proﬁles - ACE Create Examiner, ACE Create Clerk, ACE Aging Clerk and ACE Closing Clerk. See chart below:

) The Filter process is run in Tennessee Computing Center (ECC-MEM), and individual tickler ﬁles are sent to the sites for processing. The cases are created using the ACE Create Examiner proﬁle. The following RGS Case Summary Record ﬁelds are updated during the ACE Create I process: • Status Code updated to Status
or
(depending on letter stream) • Status date updated to the letter date of the CP

notice series or other ICL • Employee Group Code (EGC) updated to the EGC from the Return Transaction File • Project code (PC) updated to the PC on the Return Transaction File • Action text updated to read ICL • Action date updated to ACE run date • Type Code updated to “I” to reﬂect Initial contact • Suspense date updated to the letter date plus
or
days depending on the program requirements • Assignment to the ACE Create Examiner (

• Status date updated to the letter date (third Monday following the week the ACE program is run) • Action text updated to read Letter
• Action date updated to Letter date • Type Code updated to ‘I’ to reﬂect Initial contact • Suspense date updated to the letter date plus

Note: If correspondence is received prior to the trigger date, the Letter 525 will need to be deleted from Print Manager. In addition the AIMS update will need to be rejected from the approval screen to prevent the record from updating.
Cases in B1 inventory have limited automated actions and therefore require manual initiation. The following actions take place during B1 Create:
The ICL and report have been created and mailed to the taxpayer The case does not contain a ﬁlter condition, as outlined in IRM
, B
ACE Create/Tax Computation/Manual Review of Reports, that would cause the case to reject at the Statutory Notice or Closing process The case is correctly updated on RGS and AIMS
During the ACE Create processes, cases meeting certain ﬁlter conditions be created in Group B
These cases will appear on an inventory/ﬁlter listing, on the CEAS UCP website, with literals identifying all ﬁlter conditions that caused the case to be created in Group B
Cases do not reject to Group during the create process for a ﬁlter condition. They are created in Group with all included B
automation. Cases ﬁltered from the Create I process fall into two categories: • Project codes with a CP
notice series • Project codes with Letter
-S as the ICL and a status code update
, or Project codes with reports and a Status code update to
(12-14-2020) B2 ACE Create/Tax Computation/ManualReviewofReports

Project codes where the CP 75 notice series or Letter 566-S is generated will have an AMSTU update to Status 10. The update will need to be interfaced with AIMS. There are no reports generated on these cases, but the Letter 566-S will have packages that should be reviewed for accuracy.
Automated Correspondence Exam (ACE) Processing Overview 4.19.20
) All other cases will have the ICL and report systemically generated. An AIMS update to Status

will be sent to the Need Approval Screen. Reports need be reviewed aided by the literals on the ﬁlter listing. a. If the report is correct the letter will be printed and mailed locally. The ACE Coordinator will continue with the AIMS interface to update the status. If the case has no potential rejects, it may be reintroduced to to continue ACE processing. b. If the report is incorrect, it must be assigned to an examiner who will the following steps:
Delete the incorrect report and letter from the Case Files Documents folder.
Revise the report and save as a .pdf in the Case Files Documents folder.
Print and mail the letter.
Ensure that the mailout date matches the pending AIMS update (If it does not match, the ACE coordinator must delete the pending update so the examiner can create the correct one).
Forward the case to group B
if it has no potential rejects. (
) Cases ﬁltered from the Create II Process to Group B
will have the ICL and report systemically generated. These cases are the second phase of the CP
notice series or the Letter
-S process. Tax examiners must review the reports from each Group B

case, aided by the literals on the ﬁlter listing. If a determination is made to mail the ACE created letter and report, the letter is generated locally using the print manager function. The RGS Coordinator should place the original package in the case ﬁle document folder. If it is mined the original package will not be mailed, the case needs to be corrected. The tax examiner will prepare the letter and report and save the pdf ﬁles to Case File Documents so that they can be accessed in CEAS. If there are no reject conditions, the case may be reintroduced to the ACE process. (
) Cases meeting any of the established ﬁlter conditions will be ﬁltered from Group B
ACE Create to Group B

and the condition will be displayed on ﬁlter/inventory listing. The ﬁlter/inventory listing will display the literal of all ﬁlters encountered. Therefore, a case may have several literals. All of them must be corrected before a case is reintroduced to ACE processing. (
) The ACE ﬁlter process will also get information from CFOL. These cases are created in Group B
- AIMS Legacy (LAP) (
) During the ACE Create I process, cases receiving an ICL in Groups B
and will have an AIMS request generated in RGS to update AIMS to Status

After the ACE Create process is completed, the Legacy Access Provider process must be run to update AIMS. Coordination between the ACE Coordi- nator and the local System Administrator is necessary to reduce problems the ACE process. (

Automated Correspondence Exam (ACE) Processing Overview 4.19.20

Note: If the case is removed/rejected from the CPS transmission, remove the pending update (shown with a “P” on the RGS record) before the interface is done. This will prevent AIMS from being updated incorrectly.
) How CPS works at the Aging (Statutory Notice) stage: When the ACE Aging ﬁlters (STN Filter program) are run, the program identiﬁes the usual “ﬁlter reject conditions” and moves the case to Group B

for TE action. It also reviews each case to determine if the individual package meets the require- ments for inclusion in CPS. If the case meets the CPS requirements, it is marked for processing through the STN
process. If either of the conditions is not met, the case will not be processed through CPS and the case is processed through the STN
process.

1 Status Code to 24 (if additional 2 digits of the Status Code are present on Status 22, they will also display on Status 24) 3 For STN 01 cases – Action text updated to Auto Statutory 4 For STN 02 cases – Action text updated to Auto Statutory NPS 5 Action Date to ACE run date 6 Suspended date to the letter date plus 105/165
Status Code to 24 (if additional 2 digits of the Status Code are present on Status 22, they will also display on Status 24)
The ACE Aging program provides a copy of the report for the Statutory Notice mail out package in one of two ways.

Extracted: The report for ACE Aging will be extracted if the following conditions apply: 1 If the original report was created by ACE, 2 the “RAR_mmddhhmmss.pdf” is present in the Case File Doc folder, 3 the Tax Comp run date/time is earlier than date/time of the “RAR_mmddhhmmss.pdf”, 4 the Status on the RGS Case Summary record is not 23XX, 5 then a copy of the report will be extracted from the original ACE created PDF ﬁle. Regenerated: The report for ACE Aging will be regenerated based on the Forms/Schedules that are present in the Reports/Tax Computation screen for the following situations: 1 The ACE created PDF ﬁle “RAR_mmddhhmmss.pdf” is not present in the Case File Documents folder 2 The Status on the RGS Case Summary record is 23XX (this is regardless of whether the ACE Created PDF ﬁle is present or not) 3 The ACE Created PDF ﬁle “RAR_mmddhhmmss.pdf” is present in the Case File Documents folder, but the Tax Comp run date/time is later than the date/time on the ACE created PDF ﬁle.

Extracted: The report for ACE Aging will be extracted if the following conditions apply: 1 If the original report was created by ACE, 2 the “RAR_mmddhhmmss.pdf” is present in the Case File Doc folder, 3 the Tax Comp run date/time is earlier than date/time of the “RAR_mmddhhmmss.pdf”, 4 the Status on the RGS Case Summary record is not 23XX, 5 then a copy of the report will be extracted from the original ACE created PDF ﬁle.
If the additional two digits of the Status Code are present at the time of the ACE AMSTUS Aging process, it will update the Status in RGS to 2498.
Note: XX99 should not be used prior to the issuance of the Statutory Notice of ﬁciency. The Technique Code 7 means Undeliverable Statutory Notice.

Note: All cases for review will be randomly selected from those available. If cant problems are encountered, additional review may be needed. Review will be performed by the ACE team leader or person(s) designated by the operation. Certiﬁcation of the reviews will be provided to the Operations Manager. The Operations Managers will retain a record of the certiﬁcation. (
) When performing the output review, all of the following will be considered: • Letter, Report, all variations of Form
, and any schedules • Entity Information • Tax computation • Applicable issues addressed • Appropriate explanation given for each issue adjusted
